newsitem.title: JAPAN: NTT Docomo aims for 5 mln new subscribers in 97/98.
newsitem.headline: NTT Docomo aims for 5 mln new subscribers in 97/98.

text.p: NTT Docomo, the cellular phone subsidiary of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT), aims to acquire five million new cell phone subscribers in the year to end-March 1998, NTT Docomo president Koji Oboshi told a news conference on Friday.
This will be in addition to NTT Docomo's existing 11 million cell phone subscribers in its nationwide service.
Oboshi said, however, that the sharp growth in Japan's cell phone market will begin decelerating this year.

"We will shift our emphasis to mobile multi-media, which we expect to begin expanding (into a mass market) around the year 2000, and we hope to develop infrastructure for mobile computing and mobile multi-media services by then," he said.

NTT Docomo last month announced that it would begin an experiment on wide-band Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) digital phone networks in Japan, jointly with several major telecommunications equipment manufacturers, in 2000.
The wireless communications system would provide increased data transmission speed and system capacity and allow for video transmission.

Oboshi also said NTT group's personal handyphone system (PHS) service will incur a 75 billion yen loss in the year ending in March 1998, down from a 90.7 billion yen loss in the year ended in March 1997.
The loss in the PHS affiliate, in which NTT Docomo owns about a 45 percent share, is expected to reduce Docomo's group net profit by 32 billion yen in the current business year ending in March 1998.
NTT Docomo, which is expected to go public next autumn, has a nearly 50 percent share of Japan's booming cellular phone market.
